review_title: Plenty of good, some bad, classic healthcare nonsense
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Wheat Ridge, CO
pros: There are plenty of amazing healthcare providers where I work. They have an amazing air of wanting to teach and help coworkers improve. I'd say for every 1 bad coworker or provider, there are easily 5-10 good ones. People will give you advice if you ask for it, help you when needed, and there's a general attitude of "let's embrace the suck together" which can really be what you need to get through a rough shift. Basically, the people I work with are what really get me to stay and really see a future here.
cons: Management is... well management. There are great managers, mediocre managers, and some that just aren't great. That statement applies to all levels of management. With Intermountain integrating with what was SCL, some positions are being threatened with being let go simply because "the rest of Intermountain doesn't have this position". Good managers are getting pushed out for similar reasons or because someone who is a brown-noser wants something different even though they have no experience in that sector/specialty. Think of your classic healthcare shenanigans, "Heroes work here!" but your market adjustment counts as your raise, even though that was to keep you competitive with other employers so people would stop leaving. Also, they'll offer a new hire a 5k - 15k signing bonus (depending) but if you already work for them "you should be happy to have a job" mentality is palpable.

cons: I feel that the benefits of working at Intermountain have worsened in the past 5 years. No pension, no guaranteed Christmas bonuses, VERY limited party budgets, etc. It's the small things that Intermountain takes away that really hit the hardest. When we celebrate big anniversaries for our coworkers, we have pay ourselves and it feels silly. I want to work in a place where friendships between coworkers are really celebrated and encouraged... who wants to work with a bunch of strangers? Also- I absolutely LOATHE the current IT team. It is awful calling a tech in a different country and having to fix problems over the phone. I understand it decreases costs, but it's just impractical and obnoxious.

pros: It's a fairly easy job compared to many others I have worked and doesn't require a degree, though you will have to pass a test within your first year of working at the company. They've increased the base pay steadily since I've been here. They give 11 holidays worth of PTO per year, plus normal PTO hours based on time worked. They give good bonuses once per year, and they have some good educational opportunities.
cons: Sometimes there's a lot of work, especially in the months of Nov-Jan and you have to do overtime. Sometimes doctors and surg techs make the job stressful by putting pressure on you to do things that are not sanitary. There's not many options for growth upwards in the company. The best you can hope to become is a manager, but that will require probably 8-10 years of work before a position opens up and you have the experience, and everything above that is a bureaucratic paper-pusher position so you'll need some sort of Business degree to even be considered for those positions.

job_title: Systems Analyst in Denver, CO
pros:
- Extremely flexible work environment. Your direct manager will determine everything from what your workload will be, to the team culture, to how flexible your workday is. I can pretty much do whatever I want if I get my work done and don’t have a meeting, and that’s probably the most common situation in IT.

- not abusive. Idk maybe it’s weird that I expect my bosses to be abusive psychopaths, but these people aren’t. I have serious qualms about their strategic management, but on a day to day basis, my coworkers, my managers, and upper management are all supportive, solution oriented, and genuine. I can’t tell you how big of a difference this has made in my life. That said, there are definitely abusive managers out there, and if you get one, there’s nothing to restrain their behavior. Again, be careful on that if interviewing.
cons:
- Upper management is pretty incompetent. They regularly rename, retask, and rehouse teams in ways that hinder work, they frequently make promises they don’t intend on keeping, and start initiatives they don’t intend on finishing. Do not listen to anything a manager higher than your direct one says. 
- raises have so far not even remotely kept up with expectations, which is single-handedly causing an exodus from their IT division. In terms of what seriously determines my experience here, it’s all good with the exception of pay, which will probably eventually push me out when I would otherwise make a career here permanently.

review_title: Great coworkers and Managers/Sr. Management needs improvement for DTS Peaks Region
job_title: Systems Analyst in Washington, DC
pros:
100% REMOTE: I very much appreciate this option!

EMPLOYEES NOT PART OF SENIOR MANAGEMENT: 
Great team players and managers. They really care and most of us go way beyond what we should and are being asked to do by Sr Leadership. If it weren't for my current coworkers I would've left a long time ago but now actively looking for other employment, as are many of my coworkers are, mainly due to the lack of work/life balance.
cons:
BELOW INDUSTRY COMPENSATION FOR EQUIVALENT ANALSYST POSITIONS: 
Although of recent this is now 'under review' by Sr Management, but unfortunately many long term qualified analysts chose to leave this past year, causing even greater stress for the remaining DTS analysts to cover all existing workloads that still remain.

NO WORK/LIFE BALANCE:
Due to the non-stop unsustainable project implementation deadlines and frequent epic upgrades allowed by upper management , this is now creating extreme burnout for many Peak Region TS analysts and a recent exodus of experienced epic analysts to leave the company within the past year.

CONSTRUCTIVE FEEDBACK CANNOT BE REPORTED ANONYMOUSLY:
In other words, honest feedback is not encouraged or otherwise they'd regularly send out anonymous survey's to really find out how they are doing. 
Apparently the recent exodus of IT analysts leaving is not enough to cause them pause that maybe they aren't really listening and being supportive of those of us who make them look very successful on paper and in the media.
For the record, I personally don't trust that I wouldn't experience some type of retaliation if I did choose to submit constructive feedback using my real name, and probably same goes for most that I work with as well. Hence why constructive feedback is being reported here instead.

SUBPAR BENEFITS: to be fair, most healthcare organizations now no longer offer very affordable healthcare, just high deductible health plans.

job_title: Registered Dietitian/Certified Diabetes Educator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Excellent Benefits- dollar for dollar matching up to 4% on 401k. I locked into an okay pension (not available for employees brought on in 2020 to now), flexibility with what hours I want to work, not micro-managed, can do what I want to a certain extent, random $200 bonuses here and there that are company wide. There is definitely good work life balance, I don't do work outside of actual clinic hours.
cons:
Manager is managing a ton of people and not a dietitian, so it's hard to have them understand problems/needs. given that I'm a diabetes educator, they wouldn't let me work from home since I need to be in clinic to help with cgm/pump starts and the like. 
Since manager is covering so much, and everyone can kind of "do what they want," the nurses and MAs in my endocrinology clinic are not that comfortable with insulin (and don't have interest in gaining competence) and divert all insulin and diabetes medication refills to me, the dietitian/diabetes educator. So, I am doing a ton of Medical Assistant level admin work, which means I don't have room in my schedule to see many patients. But the clinic's argument is that we are short-staffed.

Pay is low-ish, and raises are very hard to come by. You can really only expect a 2-4% raise each year and it's not merit based...literally just a standard "cost of living" raise, which obviously does not match inflation. My understanding with speaking with other intermountain dietitians that the dietitian manager positions don't pay very much and not worth it. 

The dietitian salaries are done by tiers. So, what tier you fall in depends on your years of experience and advanced certifications. There's entry dietitian, dietitian specialist I, dietitian specialist II, and I believe there may be a level III. I was able to get a 5% raise and bumped to specialist II when I passed a second certification exam on top of my CDCES. This year, the dietitian profession at the company got a salary adjustment of 4.5% which is nice and has not happened in the 3 years I've been here, so I did get some "big" raises this year.

job_title: Nutrition Services in Provo, UT
pros: My immediate supervisor (GeorgeHuezos) was pretty great, and my immediate coworkers were very hardworking.
cons:
I worked the night shift in the dishroom, and the day crew that came before would frequently leave early, leaving us to spend the first half-hour of our shifts to clean up after them, even though they had approximately the same amount of work as us and 3.5 more hours to get it done in.
When we reported to management, if they ever bothered to come up with a solution, it was usually to make more work for us (asking us to come in earlier or work full-time on weekends). 
We were also severely understaffed. The job was a three-person job, but we frequently only had two people to do the work (and yet we still managed to get more done than day crew, because we stayed until the job was done). We would frequently need help from housekeeping (janitorial) who was also severely understaffed and oftentimes expected to clean up after kitchen staff who left them a disproportionate amount of junk after they left.
My coworkers included a young woman on the autism spectrum, a seventy year-old diabetic, and a middle aged woman who had recently had surgery on her hand. They got more done in four-and-a-half hours then the crew before us, which consisted of tall, fit men in their 20s and 30s, got done in 8. And yet nobody in management thought anything was wrong with that picture. I stuck around longer than I should have because I was worried that things would fall apart without me, and from what I've heard from a friend who still works there, it has.

job_title: Marketing Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
- Great benefits including low-cost healthcare
- Competitive pay, well over agency work
- Have a great mission
- You can skate by doing very little, and still get paid with no repercussions

I'm sure there is more, but the cons outweigh the positives for me.
cons:
To sum up the marketing department - there was no real change even after years of talking about change. Leadership is indecisive, constantly took in too many opinions, and makes NO action towards actually progressing the department to meet the demands of the market or the organization. They also were flip-floppers, constantly changing their thoughts and opinions based on the day. Leadership at the top is too focused on saving face with executive leadership. They also always try to look like they are doing something, rather than setting a clear direction so the team can actually do positive, effective work. Leadership doesn't trust the team members in the department and try to do too much themselves, and they are failing. The department (if my count is right), has lost over 20 well qualified people over the last year due to poor leadership and direction. Leaving behind lifers, or those who are unmotivated and are just going through the motions. If you want to use your skills and talents, learn and grow, this is not the place for you. You'll feel stifled, exhausted, burned out and regret your time at IHC. Much like the website, this organization is clunky, bloated, and really doesn't get the job done.

I'd avoid this team like COVID-19. They will sell you in your interview like it is all dandelions and roses, but really it is the trash bags on the streets of New York City.

Other things to note: 
- No direction
- No project management
- TERRIBLE work/life balance
- Miserable department leadership who is ALL talk, and little action
- The CMO doesn't really have a marketing background, more consumer experience
- Lots of office politics
- Have a lot of ineffective team members who can't be held accountable
- Unclear goals & objectives
- Way too focused on PR, rather then REAL marketing

job_title: Consumer Experience in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The people. To be honest, the people kept me going for a long time, but it's been hard outside of that. In the past lots of learning opportunities, but those have diminished.
cons:
I wouldn't recommend working on the marketing, consumer experience, or the consumer insight team. Marketing will say things like "We are patient focussed" but then keep doing the same things they've done for years. Unfortunately, this involves making ELT happy over patient needs. The consumer experience department is a dream of the chief marketing officer but lacks support from a lot of the executive leaders, therefore, it causes a lot of infighting and confusion among the various groups. Several people have stated we have weak leadership and I agree. Tough decisions are rarely made and drawn out over months or years. No understandable goals or priorities are set.

Most of my time here has been empty promises and dragging out processes for years that should take less than a month or two, such as hiring new employees. Many of my colleagues have left because they didn't feel their skillsets would be valued or used properly. You get hired working with a specific skill set, but because leadership is always changing their mind on the team's purpose, you become a project manager or business analyst, even though you have a completely different skill set.

The teamwork has completely disappeared. The director over consumer insights has completely changed the culture and it's much more about micromanagement and belittlement instead of empathy for patients or teamwork. It's been horrible working in this environment and mondays feel like a nightmare now.

This is a trap if you want to grow in your career because you don't work on projects long enough to build strong knowledge and 90% of projects just disappear. They tell you that you have to accept ambiguity, but this feels like a distraction because they just don't know what they are doing. Half of the time has been spent debating how to handle workflows. An uphill battle.

If they can't treat their workers right what makes anyone think it will change when it comes to the patient? If you have other options I say do that instead of working here.

Staff is overworked and underappreciated. The hospital organization is continually asking for more and more hours of work. They are trying to resolve worker burnout by telling us to care for ourselves better, while at the same time asking us to pick up two extra shifts.
During covid the need for nurses has increased, but the hospital has stopped contributing to 401k funds and has decided to no longer give a yearly bonus. They have instituted another means of bonuses, but it is unlikely that the return will be the same.
I feel it is not safe for a nurse to have such high patient ratios. It puts our licenses at risk where we to make an error due to the fact that we simply are unable to be in every patient room.
There are many physicians that still are reasonably critical of nursing staff and rude. It is an exhausting job to be a fronted on nearly every side when you're so overwhelmed trying to care for and keep patients alive.

job_title: Physician in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Used to be a great place to work.
cons: Intermountain has gone downhill fast. It used to be one of the best places to work in Utah. With the CEO changing a few years ago, it has turned into an awful place to work. Only focused on the bottom line, "bench-marking" to make us as mediocre as other health systems, and squeezing every last dollar out of their employees. I have seen nothing but cuts to staff, including vital staff like nurses and social workers. Our corporate leaders continue to survey us and we have some of lowest employee engagement scores in the nation. And yet they do nothing to remedy this. We used to have an amazing culture and satisfied caregivers who felt that the company valued them. It is amazing how quickly a culture can change! They will be facing a huge physician/nurse shortage soon as caregivers are leaving in droves.

job_title: Psychiatric Technician in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: There are incredible people that work for Intermountain who care about making a difference in people's lives. You also get to see the impact you make for patients.
cons:
However, since Marc Harrison has become CEO, they have been restructuring across the entire company with thousands being forced out of their positions.  I saw it happen on my unit back in January of 2019, they cut the Residential program for being too costly and they didn't fire anyone because it would look bad. However, it took the available shift hours from 1000 a week down to just 440. People loyal to the company, who were promised that they wouldn't lose their jobs were suddenly left with a job and zero hours, forcing them to look for work elsewhere and quit. They change policies without any regard or warning for the techs and nurses who are working on the unit, often using them as cannon fodder to throw under the bus when something is wrong because the changes that were made don't work. 

I will also flat out say that they broke several workplace laws in regards to how the employees are treated. The only things that really made it bearable were my coworkers and the patients. I left because it had become such a toxic environment.

job_title: Data Professional in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good benefits. If you have a good Manager/Director things are great. In some areas of the organization they practice what they preach. The larger organization tries to be a benevolent one.
cons:
Pay is not usually competitive, they are often trying to play catch-up. 

The organization is implementation minded with no effort to stabilize. You implement one project after another only to watch your previous project work go down the drain because senior leaders don't want you to take time to stabilize your previous work. (Then you will get asked why your previous work has failed)

I am surprised how complacent the organization is when they get a bad Director. A department can have low employee engagement, very high turnover, extremely disengaged staff, and even if all of these symptoms point back to your Director, there is NOTHING they will do about it. Don't even bother talking to HR.

The organization is going through a huge EMR overhaul implementing a new system. If you work with data or systems in any way be prepared for a crushing workload, with business owners who are not very understanding. If you can make it for the next couple years you'll probably be fine. I'm surprised how many long timers have burned out and left.

review_title: 2017 has been the worst year to work for Intermountain Healthcare
job_title: Clinical Pharmacist in Murray, UT
pros: The team I️ work with on a daily basis is amazing! We have built strong relationships of trust and have worked hard to create a positive work space in our small realm of influence.
cons:
The company culture has become very negative and has taken a steady dive ever since we have had a new CEO start with us a year ago. 
They have taken away our freedom of choice in many aspects-from no longer carrying/allowing food products that contain sugar (even such things as honey roasted peanuts), to mandating inflexible work schedules across the entire system which has negatively impacted hundreds of employees’ lives, to implementing a new/inefficient/expensive software system that has increased workloads, stress, and created a myriad of safety concerns for our patients. 
There have also been hiring freezes creating the inability to rehire for key positions when someone has left the position, as well as restrictions on overtime (for positions that would be paid an overtime rate) during this time of overwork and overwhelm. We are continually being asked to do more with less and less and less...it has become exhausting.

job_title: Psychiatric Technician in Provo, UT
pros: Some of the most amazing people work here. You feel like you are truly making a difference. I loved their health incentive with a 100 dollar bonus. They provide pretty good benefits with a matched 401k.
cons:
Also some of the worst people work here. There was a lot to learn but I didn’t get the training to match all the rules and procedures. When I made a mistake I was
made fun of and publicly humiliated. It was also really clicky like we were in high school. The night shift would have your back if you worked with them but if not they would gossip about how the others never do anything right. There was just a lot of back stabbing and bad mouthing others and management. Also if you want to get time off you will be extremely hard pressed to get your shifts covered. No one wants to work. One of the upper management nurses disliked it so much he would do two 16 hour shifts in a row just to get his hours over with for the week. You are on call sometimes as well. This was a pretty crazy place to work and getting there at 5:30 am to work a 12 hour shift was rough but I enjoyed working with the patients. I just couldn’t handle the negativity from the coworkers. Some amazing people worked there and really cared. Others had an inferiority complex and felt the need to belittle others to feel important.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Murray, UT
pros: Before Marc Harrison popped up as our CEO, Intermountain was a great place to work. I have personally worked here for many years, with experience in three different departments. We had great benefits, stable and consistent management, great teamwork, and an overall encouraging and supportive place to work. We felt confident in our abilities to serve our patients, and secure in our work environment. This is no longer the case.
cons: Marc Harrison has destroyed our sense of community, our job security, and morale. Ripping apart people's lives for what? A bigger paycheck for himself? A sense of power and importance? We are in constant worry of our departments being downsized, outsourced, or cut altogether. Where we all once felt a sense of community, we now feel an uncomfortable sense of competition; our coworkers are now our enemies, we are competing for our livelihoods.

job_title: Behavioral Health in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Reasonable pay, good benefits. Coworkers were great but beaten down by midlevel management. Esprit de corps had everything to do with caring for patients, nothing to do with the performance of management.
cons: This company is anything but a non-profit, and due to its bottom-line stance could care less about poor management in areas that are not top-grossing. This is especially true in its inpatient Behavioral Health Unit, which is located at LDS Hospital. The turnover rate under its current unit manager is 70 percent. The attitude seems to be: "let him practice at the expense of employees and patients until he gets it right. After all, it's a low grosser, and who is going to look in on mental health?" A good clinical staff provides good care despite this, but good people leave here in droves. Unless you are desperate for a job, stay away from seeking employment in that unit.

pros:

Pharmacy leadership is lacking... big time! Decisions are made behind closed doors, and movement within the department is based more on behind door promises and favortism rather than qualifications.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Intermountain Healthcare is a Utah-based, not-for-profit (but a single services model with similarities of coal towns in the 1900's) system of 22 hospitals, a Medical Group with more than 1,600 physicians and advanced practice clinicians at about 180 clinics, a health plans division called SelectHealth, and other health services. Helping people live the healthiest lives possible, Intermountain is widely recognized as a leader in clinical quality improvement and in efficient healthcare delivery.
cons: Organizational structure limitation for clinical staff and non clinical staff work with a difference of models that conflict one another. This creates a situation in which labor sacrifices on behalf of the patient to accomplish care and because the task of the care was complete the organization counts it as a win. Similar idea of losing your country and infrastructure but declaring you won the war.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Ogden, UT
pros: Loved working with fellow employees, benefits, nice facilities. The annual bonus was nice.
cons: Worked there over 17 years, loved it at first, but over the years it has gotten to the point that I felt that the company could care less about any of their employees. It’s all about us working harder to get HCAHPS scores up and make them look good, but no incentive with lower pay than the other hospital systems and not feeling valued. Administration places some people in management positions who micromanage, are lazy, and will do whatever they ask to save money, which can affect staff and/or patient care. When presented with problems, they downplay them or turn it around on the presenter, because they don’t want to believe it’s a problem or address concerns.

job_title: Planning in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Was a great company where you used to be able to plan a career and make a difference in peoples lives.
cons:
The glass ceiling at Intermountain is actually a concrete ceiling. In a glass ceiling, a woman would be able to see how to move to upper management, but be unable to do so. As the following will demonstrate, the promotional doors to upper leadership are not offered to women. Intermountain has very few female leaders in its top levels (VP, SVP, and C Suite.) The few female leaders who are at that level have been leaving the organization (Previous Chief Operating Officer, the departing Chief Nursing Officer...)

The information in this review draws from senior leaders public teleconferences and general announcements to employees, so nothing here has been labelled confidential. I removed peoples names and just use their titles because this isn't directed at an individual, but the overall machismo culture that has taken over at Intermountain Healthcare executive  levels.

The organization stated publicy where it builds its new executive leaders from, the Enterprise Initiatives Office, which is  under the Chief Strategy Officer (male) and Chief Operating Officer (male). In a recent public teleconference for the Scottsdale Institute, he explained explained that this  office is the incubator for future Intermountain executive team members. It's the door through the glass ceiling, so if you get in, you get access to the highest paying opportunities. (highly recommend listening to this just do a web search for it)

How does one apply to be a part of this incubator? One doesn't. The leadership 'appointments' of this group are apparently only given to men. This is demonstrated to employees over numerous emails.  Take for example the statements to employees regarding the series of high level promotion opportunities for which there is no opportunity for women to apply:

In an August 8 email, the CEO  stated simply described the process as this man  "will become" the Chief Strategy Officer and Vice President. No invitation to apply, no announcement of opportunity, no attempt to find qualified candidates. No opportunity for the majority female candidates in the company to apply. In a September 24 email, the Chief Strategy Officer who was suddenly now promoted to Senior Vice President instead of just being the vice president he was the month before (it pays to be on the insid), announced more lucrative leadership opportunities were being given to additional men.
"[a male] has been appointed Vice President of the Enterprise Initiative Office..."
"[another male] has been appointed Vice President of the Market Intelligence and Planning Office..."

(As pointed out in the teleconference, which you really should listen to for yourself, the only woman to 'advance' out of the incubator was a woman who was promoted "out of the company". The Chief Strategy Officers email to employees about it he said he "was sad to see her leave Intermountain". We were too. Intermountain needed female leaders. )

Compare this appointing process in contrast to the process many female leaders go through:
A September 12 announcement for an Executive Nurse Director states she went through a "selection". Or when the announcement regarding the departure of the chief nursing officer (one of the few remaining female executives), in a position which is typically female the CEO stated the process for getting this position will involve "A national search is underway to fill [the] role" It is frustrating to see the incubator for executive opportunities so closed here, wouldnt it be nice if women could be just appointed to positions like the men in the executive incubator.

Unfortunately it continues. A few months ago my area was moved under a Decision Support analytics team. The new leadership opportunity for the combined groups was never announced to the women and we were never given the opportunity to apply despite several on the team having much more experience than the man to whom we were told to report. All the leadership positions in this team are filled by men already, so there is no opportunity for women to advance. Women who left that team earlier said that the men on the team were similary promoted into their roles with no real opportunity for women to apply. One woman who spoke up about the situation are no longer with the company. Now the leader of this combined group has been telling the male leaders that he will be the new Vice President of Analytics. We dont have one of those. So it appears that yet another executive position has been minted and promised to a male with no opportunity for more experienced females to apply or be given access to the developmental leadership opportunities given to less experienced men.

That's why I titled this women need not apply. It sure looks like there  is a door through the glass ceiling into executive leadership at Intermountain, because they are constantly announcing men who have been appointed through it. But the lock onthe door apparently requires an XY chromosome pair. XX doesn't even get you an opportunity to apply.

Before this post gets buried by suspiciously brief rosy posts to bury it, I invite Intermountain's communication team to let us know how many many females applied for each of the leadership promotional opportunities mentioned here. I could very well be wrong. I hope we followed our policies and there were lots of women candidates and that somehow I am just missing every announcement about all the executive promotion opportunities.

review_title: Great place to start a career
job_title: Charge Nurse in Saint George, UT
pros: Intermountain has a lot of great facilities to begin a career, many fantastic benefits including health, 401k, PTO, and a wellness program called LiVeWell along with several other things that make this a great place to work. Staff and management are friendly and approachable. It is a very good work environment in comparison to many hospitals.
cons: Wages are on the lower end of the spectrum, as is healthcare in general in the state of Utah. There are opportunities to advance your career, but it only goes so far as the upper level positions seem to be taken by people who “know people” rather than workers who are adequately qualified.

review_title: I've worked for several healthcare corporations and this is the best by far
job_title: Clinical Area Manager in Ogden, UT
pros: The community atmosphere at IHC is very strong. You can rely on your co-workers to help you and the hospitals have a family unit type of feel because everyone it seems genuinely cares about everyone else.  I would trust my family's care only to IHC.  They go through extensive work to make decisions via solid data and evidence.  The resources for decision based care are incredible.
cons: There's no sitting back as an employee, you are required to constantly strive to give more.  Sometimes that can be exhausting for the amount of pay we receive.  They also tend to hire idiot consulting firms like Stockamp Huron. We have to put our hospital back together after they leave.  No one seems to understand the frustration.

review_title: Great culture of accountability, mutual respect, and innovation
job_title: Business in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Everyone has a voice, leadership is well aligned on delivering on their commitments, transparency in interactions
cons: Many decisions take potentially longer than they should.  There is often a cross functional team approach to problems which can make a week long decision into a year long decision...however, this can also be a bit of a "pro" when multiple viewpoints are considered.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
•The simulation department is full of amazing people. Especially the system-level management. The manager and director really fight for you, and want you to succeed and provide any tools/support you need to grow in your position.  I love my team very much.  Everyone is very friendly and fun and are professionals in their field. 
• We run a wide variety of simulations. Every day is different. It keeps things fresh and exciting and consistently provides opportunities for innovation. 
•The Intermountain Simulation department is an accredited program 
• Lots of room to grow your career. And management genuinely WANTS you to succeed, even if it means you leave the team.  They will provide any support to help you in your career goals. 
• The Intermountain Simularion team is considered an industry leader.  We are years ahead of the majority of other simulation departments across the country.
cons: • The same exact position across the country, in different hospitals/universities makes roughly  $20k more. Utah severely underpays its simulation employees.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Denver, CO
pros:
I am on the system side, so I am not a clinical associate, but from what I have seen the overall company is a great place to work.  Because they have combined two well known companies, SCL Health is very innovative in bringing a unified work place to the company.  The directors and managers really listen to associates and do their best to put ideas in to action.  

My team in particular provides a great work life balance!
cons:
You have to use PTO for company holidays, but that is very similar to other health systems.   Bereavement leaves A LOT to be desired, you would think a hospital system would understand death a bit more.  
Former Exempla (Denver care sites) have a better tuition plan than system or any other care sites.

job_title: IT Infrastructure in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Terrific mission
Low turnover 
Good work life balance 
Reasonable PTO accrual rate
Low insurance premiums 
Flexible work scheduled 
Financially Stable
Staff dedicated to company mission and vision.
cons:
Under new management (CEO).
Like all new CEOs he has s trying to make his mark. Unfortunately that mark is to outsource 1000s of dedicated employees (2300 In Revenue Cycle org are in midst of rebadging and a few more hundred IT employees are on deck to be next). These changes will negate many of the pros listed above.

review_title: Great company in a good industry
job_title: Senior Accountant in Broomfield, CO
pros: Co-worker are like extended family.  People genuinely care about their roles and work.  Non profit mentality makes a HUGE difference.  Fun environment with good challenges.  Very reliable IT systems.  State of the art corporate facility.  Great management.  It's the best place I have worked in a 20 year career.
cons: Management admits to paying lower than industry average but hasn't addressed discrepancy.  Only managers and above are financially rewarded for company performance.  Low annual pay increases.  Location of corporate office is in an expensive area, making relocation closer to work prohibitive.  Mass transit is not an option due to office location.

job_title: Staff Auditor II in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Pay is good, work life balance is great.
cons: Management actively discriminates against LGBT people.  If you have a doctors appointment that will take more than two hours they require you to take the entire day off.  Feedback is vague and often lacking in specifics and is therefore not actionable.  If they decide they don’t like you they will make life miserable to force you to quit.  They are also not above lying about why they are terminating you.  All but two members of IA’s management team have any integrity and the Chief Audit Officer is very anti-LGBT.  The department has a VERY high turnover ratio.

job_title: NICU RN in Murray, UT
pros: Great patient care and staff
cons: Marc Harrison, CEO, doesn't care about the patient:RN ratio. Sometimes we don't feel that he cares about our concerns. The rest of Leadership genuinely seems to care about our thoughts and concerns and lets us know that we have been heard.

job_title: Director in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Board and executive leadership has set ambitious expectations for the company. Mission, vision, values as well as history are inspiring.
cons:
Executive Leadership is trying to force too much change at once, pursuing too many priorities, not valuing candid feedback and struggling to be consistent.
Cuts are happening without consistent efforts to “separate the wheat from the chaff.” This is understood by employees and sadly employees are becoming less engaged and fearful. Employee buy in is at a low and values are not being upheld. “A” players are now leaving the company. As a customer of healthcare at Intermountain I am now experiencing the low morale effecting service.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Murray, UT
pros: Great training, lots of resources, room for advancement and education reimbursement. Most frontline staff genuinely love what they do! It’s amazing to be a part of that and working next to people that want to help others the way you do.
cons: Cuts backs to many departments, micro management, constant threats of raises being withheld if not able to meet unreasonable goals. Very strict policies, if something is in the “grey area” managers error on the side of Intermountain instead of employee, for fear of their own job. The morale is at an all time low (worked there for 12 years).

review_title: Well-Managed Healthcare Group that Pays Poorly
job_title: Financial Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Intermountain is enormous, stable, and supportive.  Management knows what they're doing and executes well.  If you want to work in health care in Utah, Intermountain is the leading employer.
cons:
The pay is sad.  Raises are even sadder.  

The mystery is why, with such mediocre compensation, so many employees have stuck around for so long.  In fact, there are enough lifers that getting a meaningful promotion is next to impossible.  The office is full of dead-end jobs

job_title: Business Analyst in South Salt Lake, UT
pros: Collaborative team based environment, everyone has a voice at the table, easy access to senior leadership, well developed structure (in my group) for career planning and leaders that help you sculpt a plan to achieve your own individual goals, commitment to making employees work experiences richer and more meaningful
cons: No forced turnover in most groups, even when there are low performers. Tougher for energetic and idea driven younger individuals to supplant incumbents. Tenure can be a real barrier to entry in some roles. Highly motivated individuals will not wait decades for their 'turn'

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint George, UT
pros: co-workers got along with most. enjoy being a nurse in general aside from this company
cons:
pay is terrible and the company wants you to be "so grateful to them that you get to work for IHC"  whereas it should just be pay me what I'm worth to do my job well. 
Additionally, they ask you to donate a part of your pay check back into the companies pocket. This pressure was very uncomfortable. If you ever, ever make an error they start a "paper trail" this is to let you never forget any mistakes and when your raise comes up to bring any and all transgressions ever done thus you don't deserve a decent raise. 
Lastly when I put in notice they reminded me over and over how I would regret ever leaving IHC.  I have never regretted this decision.

review_title: How many peoples’ livelihoods can one destroy before something is done?
job_title: Registered Nurse in Saint George, UT
pros: Wonderful, hard working, loyal and dedicated co-workers whom truly care about their patients.
cons: Management makes you feel like you’re all disposable and replaceable. Completely unappreciated. Weeding out all the old and replacing them w/the brand new because they’re paid less, or simply outsourcing. Upper management implementing changes to clinical setting of which they’ve never stepped foot into. Continually adding more and more to everyone’s plate w/little to no care for our it’s effecting the caregivers and/or their patients.

job_title: CT Tech in Murray, UT
pros: Great Radiologists.   Good pay and benefits for the area.
cons: Lazy, entitled Techs who whine constantly about being overworked and underpaid.   It’s not everywhere that you can sit and watch two or three sports games at the same time while you scan a patient.    It’s not everywhere where you can have breakfast, lunch and dinner and complain you’re too busy on a 10 hour shift while getting paid for the entire 10 hours.  Then yes, clock out no lunch because you are so so busy.  It’s not generally excepted most places where you can swear at each other and tell each other off, talk filthy, think it’s cute and funny and then blame someone else for it.   It’s not everywhere where the managers and upper management condone this kind of situation and sometimes are a big part of it.

job_title: Respiratory Therapist in Butte, MT
pros: If you are a recent graduate in any field you have a good chance of getting a job at St. James.  They like to hire people with no experience at the bottom of the pay scale.  The cost of living in Butte is reasonable.
cons: Communication and respect from middle and upper management to the real workers is not present.  Most of those in management came from within and have no leadership skills.  Our hospitalist provider has been unable to supply the hospital with quality physicians.

review_title: For the CEO Marc: "Excellence: We perform at the highest level, always learning and looking for ways to improve."
job_title: Medical Coder in Murray, UT
pros: Impacting the lives a patients in a non clinical sense. Creating ease during the worst moments of patients lives.
cons: micro managing to the amount of clicks a minute. No room for growth or moments in careers. Basically has turned into a medical conditioning sweat shop. You are expected to take on 30% more of processing in the same 8hrs, no OT. and if you don't meet those numbers just once in a quarter say good bye to your .25 cent performance raise.

review_title: Loved the people I worked with
job_title: EKG Tech in Murray, UT
pros: Pretty decent pay for not having a degree. The work was not to difficult. I really loved a lot of my coworkers.
cons: The higher ups made everything difficult for us working the actual jobs, they only care about saving a few bucks for themselves. It doesn’t feel like we’re in the business to help save people it’s more like a hotel business, how can we make them more happy so we can get a better score.  The actual job, as an ekg tech is a lot of responsibility even though your not a doctor your still expected to tell the doctor everything you see on the ekg and if you miss something and the doctor doesn’t check himself you get in trouble not them which is ridiculous.

review_title: Just a number to the company.
job_title: Software Engineer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Being able to move up from starting jobs to Jr.-Sr. positions.
Strive to have a healthy employee base. (No Smoking - Weight reduction...)
Great place to work and hide.
cons:
Just like working for government with less pay. Lower management run departments like fiefdoms. One of the four managers experiences were positive. 

To much distance between Human Recourses and employee's. I got the feeling that HR was just there to support managers and protect the company. 

I felt that my health was tied to my ability to work for this company.

One bad manager (3 years) can destroy a good working environment of (13 years).

review_title: Used to be a great place to work until the end of  2017
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ogden, UT
pros: Was a great place to work at one point have been with Intermountain, almost 10 years.  Great Pay is about the only thing I can think of as a pro.
cons: With changes to management and trying to make parts of Intermountain a flat company,  their is no direction, no leadership, the CEO and the board of directors along with  partners do not care about the employees or what isn't working and and they say they listen, but they are not fixing anything, people are leaving at a high rate and you are expected to do more than your full time job.

review_title: You get to know how the healthcare system works
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: As a not-for-profit, there is really a feeling that the patient is the top priority, rather than any shareholders like at other companies.  Very stable place to work.  Compensation is fair.  I really get to know how many of the processes work in health care and how government gets involved with regulations.
cons:
Very slow moving when it comes to technology.  There are lots of opportunities for new innovations, but the bureaucracy slows things down so much it's hard to get to them.
While compensation is fair, that is all, as it is based on industry averages.  HR methods are outdated with performance review methods and job ladder limited besides to go into management.

job_title: Digital Marketing Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: This is a great place to work with good people and the opportunity to do marketing for a huge healthcare brand. Intermountain is really just getting started with digital marketing, so there are a lot of opportunities there.
cons: Marc Harrison is currently making a lot of changes to the structure of the company (marketing especially), and it's not clear what those changes are going to be. The general feeling is one of foreboding. The company is also often stymied in bureaucracy and leadership have a tendency to be penny wise and pound foolish.

job_title: Lead Therapist in Denver, CO
pros: I work with some awesome talent.  We take our jobs quite seriously, but still manage to have fun.  It's an environment where initiative is highly valued and rewarded, and where it feels safe to learn, grow, and make mistakes.
cons: Occasionally, it feels as though the larger organization is out of touch with the day to day work.  For example the larger organization may want or value some change without thinking through how it impacts the front line staff.  However, I have found that voicing these concerns often gets them solved or changed.

review_title: If leadership only cared to listen and value employees
job_title: Recruitment in Murray, UT
pros: Benefits, 401k, pension - but not worth career unhappiness and dissatisfaction
cons: Leadership doesn't care about the employees who have believed in the company and its mission and have given their commitment for years. They don't provide opportunity for career growth and hire contract employees who don't know policy and best practices and think quantity over quality. They're hiring the worst people to provide care for patients. This contradicts the company's mission and healing commitments. This place is sinking and turnover and Gallup proves it. You can't voice your opinions without it affecting your job stability and growth. I don't want to be a patient or an employee for a company that is failing at what it says it stand for. The benefits don't beat the lack of care and value leadership has for its employees. Recruitment should be an example of best practices and following policies but it is just politricks and crooked leadership.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint George, UT
pros: The pay and benefits are decent, great commute. A lot of employee appreciation events, good food in the cafes. Some mangers actually know what they're doing.
cons: They are paralyzed with fear over terminating failing executives, but think nothing of using any excuse--even a bald-faced lie--to terminate diligent employees who only want to prop up the appearances shaken by weak leadership. The had been whimpering a lot about budgets, but didn't even blink when a department paid over $4,000 for a chandelier in temporary office space. They don't consistently follow their own policies. Only when it benefits THEM.  Some leadership seems to just be biding time until retirement so all the chaff  developed under their watch will become someone else's problem.

job_title: Pre Registration Specialist in West Valley City, UT
pros: Some of the best reasons to work at Intermouontain Health Care would be that most departments work with your school schedual, another reason would be that IMC have a more than a few facilities around the salt lake valley which gives you options to move around.
cons: This company is not always about what you know or what you have learned or achieved in school, but more along the lines of who you know and where you work that have higher people that can help you move up in the company.

job_title: Pharmacist in Provo, UT
pros: Organized, professional, friendly co-workers, managers work hard to ensure every employee has the tools and skills they need to do a good job. Intermountain values their employees and does a lot of fun things for us like fun runs, meal certificates to reward above-and-beyond sort of workers, summer parties, discounts at tons of places, etc.
cons: Sometime you end up parking pretty far from the part of the hospital where you work. There's a little bit of politics involved in employment here, sometimes it's not what you know it's who you know that gets you a job.

review_title: Feel good about the work you do
job_title: Systems Support Tech in West Valley City, UT
pros: Great pay - great benefits - felt like the IT support work I did really made a positive impact for patients and employees - PTO was very generous and managers allowed me to take over a paid month off after my wife had our first child. If you're good at your job there is a lot of room for upward mobility. Work from home is available in many IT departments.
cons: Feedback and communication between the many IT departments is lacking. Lots of changes and things happening felt reactionary and not always well tested for QA. I was the last direct hire in my dept, we started hiring through contract tech temp agencies, though most techs were eventually hired on after the end of their contract.

job_title: Enhanced Registrar in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: There aren't many, but they do like to promote from within. They match your contribution to your HSA which is nice. They do tuition reimbursement after 6 month with the company.
cons: Employees are underpaid, under appreciated, and over worked. IHC wants you to work for them because you care for patients, which is nice, but if you're also looking to be compesated fairly for your work, look elsewhere. Their insurance premiums continue to rise, and their insurance packages aren't good as it is. They are drastically reducing the amount that they give out for christmas bonuses, eventually wanting to get rid of them entirely. They are re-structuring and getting rid of employees left and right. Management is not good, they believe a high five should been enough compensation for a extraordinary work....

review_title: Not Good! Soon to be former employee...
job_title: Soon to BE Unemployed in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Nothing really anymore other than I'd say about 95% of the employees is great to work with.  Very professional.
cons:
Outsourcing, OUTSOURCING!!!

They don't care about their employees anymore.  About 10 yrs ago it was a great place to work but now with bad corporate decisions it is making it impossible to like working here anymore.  I feel bad for the employees that'll eventually be let go, but who will really suffer (and I feel bad for) in the long term is the clinical staff and patients because they won't get as great of support service as they once had.

review_title: I Would Never Recommend My Friends...
job_title: Human Resources in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Healthcare is a strong field and Intermountain Healthcare is a strong and stable organization.
cons: It takes years for anything to change because there are so many hoops and ladders. I felt like my opinions didn't matter. Overworked and underpaid. Salaries don't even match the market; they are lower. The HR department was hypocritical and didn't follow their own rules. Too much time was wasteid in meetings. People were often hired without the proper training/background/experience/credentials and then fired when they didn't succeed. There was way too much of "hiring our friends" rather than hiring the qualified candidate. It's no surprise to see so many people fail when that is the approach that is being taken.  Intermountain spends all of its time preaching their values but don't live them with their own employees.

job_title: Analyst in Denver, CO
pros: Flexibility to work remote, great working team, great healthcare benefits (insurance through Cigna is affordable), great retirement package after you've been there 5 years
cons: No maternity leave (you have to utilize FMLA/disability to obtain a % of pay for a handful of weeks then utilize your PTO, which you only get 3 weeks of per year which is also consumed for holidays...and you can only keep 180 hrs or so per year, making it impossible to roll over and utilize for maternity leave...so essentially you risk your job and/or not getting paid if you choose to have children), no assistance/day care opportunities available, reactive decision-making at upper level, little opportunities for advancement, poor pay compared to other Denver hospitals, poor raises (1% or so per year, even for "good" employees).

job_title: Financial Analyst Senior in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
The people that you get a chance to work with are usually great.
The work/life balance is very good as well.
Stability - the threat of layoffs is low.
cons:
The employee benefits used to be the best reason to work there. They have consistently made them worse in the past couple of years. 

There is no loyalty. I have seen many people get screwed out of promotions they should have received. For some reason, the employees continue to stay because of their strong cultural ties to the area. This has led to the company consistently giving lower salaries to their employees.

job_title: Pediatric RN in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I love my workplace, patients, co-workers and management. Everyone works as a team and we've truly become a family. I've never felt this kind of camaraderie in any other workplace.
cons: Scheduling is really tough. If I had this schedule at any other work place, I would have quit long ago. My patients and coworkers are what keep me at my job because I truly love working with them. Management has recently hired travel nurses, which has decreased our floating requirements, which makes the hard turn arounds less stressful.

job_title: Clinical Quality Improvement Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Pay and benefits were excellent.
cons: Management and human resources didn't follow their own policies for eliminating positions. Show very little concern for their employees well being. I watched one supervisor eliminate eight people in a very impatient, manipulative way before it was my turn. In my case, my supervisor imposed extra requirements that made it impossible to keep up with regular work, which was not imposed on colleagues.

job_title: Software Engineer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Management seems to "get it" with respect to technology -- they see the value and invest resources to capitalize on technology.  Fantastic, friendly team.  It hardly feels like "work" because everyone on my team are great friends.  There's plenty of room for creativity within your project.  Hours are flexible.  There is a dedicated support structure, so you don't spend your development time answering support calls.  The senior management really want Intermountain to be a good place to work, and it shows.
cons: The pay is average, and the opportunities for advancement are slim.  Seniority seems more important than your job performance, so you don't have much chance of moving up the ladder if you weren't one of the first few people on a team.  Benefits are alright, but health insurance is the worst of anywhere I've been (ironic, right?).

review_title: Culture of Honesty and work-life balance set Intermountain apart
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Huge emphasis on work-life balance and remaining mentally and physically healthy. Programs to ingrain a friendly atmosphere. The policy for coworkers is "assume good intent".  Managers who don't just seem to care - they really do.  Repeated employee satisfaction surveys to make sure they are on track. Very low turnover. Consistently ranked one of the best places to work in Utah.  Never had a layoff.
cons: Low turnover has its minuses. Promotions are hard to come by when nobody leaves. Career advancement will be more likely due to growth of the organization and new positions being created. It is not uncommon to work with people with 30+ years experience and it takes a long time to earn your 'Street cred'

job_title: Director in Denver, CO
pros: Lots of good people work here
cons: Senior Leadership cant seem to get all the hospitals to work as a system. The sites just want what they want and they do not care about any cost savings, efficiencies or benefits of standardizing their systems and services.  I know of many people in both management and staff positions that are looking for jobs else where.  The work life balance is something that is talk about a lot but project volume and completion requirements have many working very long days with no end in site.  It has been like this for many years.

review_title: Great job stability, however career advancement is very slow.
job_title: Budget Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Very large corporation for the market; Consistently beats budget even in bad economy. Very tech oriented, high level of computer literacy is expected.
cons: Very tech oriented, high level of computer literacy is expected. If you are not tech savvy this is probably not the best place to work.  Pay is atrocious compared to level of work and technical ability that is expected.  Be prepared to work well out of the bounds of your roll, this is both a pro and con good experience but salary is very bad. The biggest con is that there is a regimented structure at administrative level, if you did not go to one of the preferred schools, it is very difficult to climb corporate ladder.   Not impossible but more difficult.

job_title: IT Systems in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Intermountain is a great place to work. Aside from the pension AND 401K matching, they try to espouse some great mutual respect values between employees. This creates a culture where ideas and suggestions are welcomed and considered, and you're left with a sense that your opinion matters. 

As far as technology goes, Intermountain is on the cutting edge of many technologies and is constantly looking for ways to leverage technology to improve patient care outcomes. This is the best IT job I've had in my career of 18 years. Hope to spend many more years employed here.
cons: Some typical IT challenges. Being on the cutting edge requires constant change and that can be a challenge for some people.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint George, UT
pros: It was a great company at one time!
cons: They are in for the money.  Employees are a dime a dozen and the company shows no loyalty to dedicated workers who have given years of their life  to IHC.  Religion plays a huge part to fit in the culture at Intermountain.  It appears that older workers with experience are leaving and are being replaced with young inexperienced workers at a lower wage. This may be due to financial gains for the company or due to age discrimination.   Most older worker are custodians and not higher paying clinicians. Look for yourself and you decide. One of the lowest pay in the nation!

job_title: Patient Care in Logan, UT
pros: My family has worked with this company for as long as I've been alive. It is a great place to work! They really focus on taking care of the patient as a person and are consistently improving their care. Benefits are phenomenal!  I have never seen coverage like it. From incentive programs(where they pay to be healthy and manage stress) to healthcare coverage there is always someone you talk to about you and your family. I highly recommend it to anyone.
cons: It can be very hard to get in. Once you are in though, you're there. Due to high application income the screening can be brutally. If you answer one question wrong, your application doesn't ever make it to a person to look at. Make sure all your certifications (BLS, CPR, ect) are update before you apply

review_title: It used to be in a great place to work at still has some really good people but executive leadership is driving the ment
job_title: Senior Solutions Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The people that you work with are great and the pay time off as great as well as the health care insurance
cons: Where the biggest challenges is the director of the CEO. he has pretty much ruined the Homegrown roots of the company and a lot of great people have been leaving because of many reorganization s

job_title: Administrator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Extremely high standards of excellence,  quality,  and team work.  Professional, clean, and safe work environment.  Rewards for Live Well healthy eating, exercising, emotional & mental health for all employees w/ Web monitoring and suggested goals and tracking, including managing stress as well as practical issues such as relationships and personal finances.
cons: Sometimes in such a large regional organization, it becomes difficult to draw in all the various personalities and work styles onto the same page.  There are avenues to help find solutions to any conflict or offense, however,  they are not always initiated by all parties.

job_title: Finance Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Benefits - pension, PTO, 401K match.  The actual caregivers/co-workers are great and care for the patient.
cons:
No upward mobility - waste a lot of time working for promotion but those come only by seniority.  It is a company that rewards mediocrity and punishes those who want to work hard and climb.  
From the top down the management is feeding their people and the communities a thick Kool-Aid; they are not a Not-For-Profit in the way they behave.  And they are definitely not the company I joined in the early 2000’s.  They are very much profit driven and their leaders are full of themselves.

review_title: The absolute best of the best!!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: "If there is an ideal out there…it can be seen in the kind of medicine already being practiced by Kaiser Permanente, the Mayo Clinic, Intermountain Healthcare, and Geisinger Health System, which manage to hold down costs and get better results. Their operations have fostered closer teamwork among care providers."  - Time Magazine
cons: I wish they would allow non-clinical staff more opportunities to work remotely.  Other than that I can honestly say there are no other "cons".  I have worked in Healthcare for 25+ years and this organization is by far second to none.

job_title: Software Engineer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Pros: Stable, flexible
 
Work environment -  Flexible . People are nice (depends on the team :) ) and  I do enjoy working here because manager and colleagues are considerate for family life and yet you get to work hard on problems you enjoy ( Yes your preference for type of work you like to do is considered )

Critical deadlines - We do have release for products planned and those days probably are more hectic but for the rest of the days you get to choose how you want to complete your work. Your capacity ( as in hrs ) is decided before work is assigned to you. 

General Overall Impression: Its a great company but you have to keep looking to get into a team where they have projects you like.
cons: Things happen little slow than  tech companies.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Provo, UT
pros: Coworkers are great - there's kind of an "us against them" feeling among hourly employees
cons: No real training at all for pharmacy techs in the compounding lab. You are just dropped in and expected to learn from coworkers. Also, there are no accessible written procedures, so everyone does things their own way. The company constantly stresses "do no harm" but does very little in the way of actually making sure the techs have the ability to properly perform their jobs.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Unity among other Recruiters and support staff. Majority of the hiring managers are outstanding and extremely coachable when  dealing with hiring issues. A wonderful sense of "doing what is right" for the community.
cons: Previous AVP and HR Directors,  within the corporate office were unethical. Company mission, vision and values were adhered to a selected few. The key phase "Work, Llife, Balance" was never a goal based on workload and unrealistic expectations.

review_title: Great Company exceptional care for employees and patients!
job_title: Registered Nurse in Provo, UT
pros: Most of the people I have have worked with are genuine and caring people, they work as a team and are always there for each other. After 5 years you are vested with the company. Great work environment.
cons: The pay raises are not consistent with performance, and the beginning pay for a new RN is lower than most of the other Utah companies

review_title: Leadership struggles to understand how to run IS projects

review_title: Have never been treated like this before!
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Layton, UT
pros: Made me glad I can afford not to work!

review_title: Good work environment, but underpaid, dead-end job.
job_title: Anonymous in Denver, CO
pros: The people are usually nice, and there is a good work/life balance.   Health insurance and dental are decent, and they contribute a few percent if you participate in the retirement plan.
cons: My job title in the payroll system is different, lower, and in no way representative of my actual job title.  Have tried to get it corrected for years, but HR ignores my requests.  Bonuses for the same performance rating have dropped by about half.  Less vacation time can be carried over from previous years.  Haven't had even a 2% cost of living raise in the last few years.  The more you work, the more they make you tighten your belt.  This is no way to motivate employees.

job_title: Middle Manager in Ogden, UT
pros: Good benefits.  Enough good employees to achieve success in spite of neurotic executive team.
cons:
Nilly willy senior leadership who focus on making a name for themselves without respect to employees.  Middle managers chosen more for ability to toe the party line than for being top-notch.  
Many recent corporate initiatives in revenue cycle, productivity improvement, and supply chain have been very poorly executed with bad results due to incompetent leadership mostly recruited from inside and staffed with insiders without specific experience.  The organization could do much better that the VPs and AVPs attempting to lead these efforts.

job_title: Nurse in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I had great co-workers here and was paid well.
cons: Extremely money hungry. The higher up and big wigs only care about money. Seriously. They're all about doing favors to people and don't care about stepping on anyone's toes while they're at it. They ask for advice from employees then don't follow it. They have fired multiple friends of mine then replaced them with family friends... Seems sketchy? Yeah. It is. All they care about it making money. It has been declining for the past 10 years and will continue. Stay away.

review_title: A company headed in the wrong direction
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Denver, CO
pros: My immediate group and managers are good, however they can't make up for upper management.  Benefits are okay.
cons: No career path for my position, with no chance for salary increases.  The company has never fully integrated from the merger several years ago and the current CEO is leading the company down the wrong path.  No true concern for employees despite the constant lip service to the company mission and values.  They send out the annual survey to all associates, but never listen to the feedback.

review_title: Mark Harrison is a narcissistic micromanager
job_title: Registered Nurse in Provo, UT
pros: None anymore because of Mark Harrison
cons: The new ceo mark Harrison is so selfish he can’t even think straight. He micromanages everyone and everything and took sugar away from the hospital. Really? Are we not all adults here who can decide what we eat? He has cut bonuses, slashed jobs, driven many people to quit, micromanaged, adds stupid tasks and goals to our already insane workload, ups patient to nurse ration while penalizing if we clock out 1 minutes late, and has ZERO care for anyone but himself in this job. Do not work for IHC, I just quit and it was the most freeing thing! No longer under his freaking dictatorship.

job_title: Healthcare Provider in Grand Junction, CO
pros: The people in the community are beautiful. They are poorly misrepresented by this hospital.
cons: Among decades of wonderful & uplifting occupational healthcare experiences, being a provider for St. Mary's has been the sole dreadful undertaking of my career. In retrospect, I can now acknowledge the mistake I made in signing with this organization. From one provider to another in consideration of the sacrifices we make to become who we are and earn the honor to care for our patients, I feel obliged to advise you to carefully contemplate your options on your next practice site. Out of preservation of your self-worth, I embolden you to choose an entity other than St. Mary's Hospital in Grand Junction.  I regret my decision wholeheartedly and wish someone had been upfront with me about their experience.

review_title: Mission and Values driven, authentic, well intentioned, not perfect, better than peer employer.
job_title: in Murray, UT
pros: Try very hard to get feedback from employees.  Live their mission.  Non-profit, supports community with huge amounts of charity care.  Very successful, they win in the marketplace.  Smart and competent colleagues.  Try very hard to balance, cost control, employee engagement, healing, and community stewardship.  Strong, healthy, intentional culture.
cons: Some employees have sense of entitlement and are out of touch with competitive nature of business.  Maybe too insulated.  "Nice" culture can interfere with tough conversations and difficult decisions.  Pay must be regionally aligned as size of organization really is the immediate market, forcing smaller players to pay higher, gives perception of lower wages.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I love the Benefits and the staff here at Intermountain. It is a positive environment and everyone is always willing to help and support everyone else!
cons: We are Medical Assistants in charge of so many different responsibilities, we are the Physicians "right hand" but we are paid........lets just say I made more before going to school and as a teenager. But I love taking care of patients....what to do?

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
There are (have been) a lot of good people throughout the organization.  
People will still get sick, so the company will be around a while.
cons:
The company has lost the vision of community healthcare that it was founded on.
The board has brought in a high priced outsider CEO to accomplish the desired change of direction.  Absolutely no prior reputation or expectation of the company is reliable and valid.  Beware!  Modest wage, uncertain security.

review_title: Great place to work if getting a competitive & fair salary is not important to you.
job_title: Project Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great place to work, market leader with lots of innovation happening.  Reasonable resources made available to you.
cons: They abuse their size and position in the market to offer salaries that feel like an insult.  There is also a lot of middle management hell bent on maintain the status quo and not letting young talent advance until they have “paid their dues” because that is what they had to do.

job_title: Finance Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Job security, pension, work-life balance, 401K match, competitive healthcare options and premiums.
cons: Poor growth opportunities.  Too many managers promoted above their abilities.  For a long while IHC promoted based on seniority and they never fire so there are a ton of horrible managers.  Lately, Human Resources started to encourage hiring managers to hire externally so anybody of any value already in the company gets overlooked for external candidates.  The culture and system facilitates mediocrity.  My manager is one of those managers promoted above his abilities and has absolutely no social skills.  He feels he has to make everybody else look bad to provide himself opportunities for good raises in the future.  Most managers are "Yes Men" so there are rarely any new ideas.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The company mission and values are something I really like to uphold, it attracted me to the company to begin with. The healthcare professionals love what they do and work hard to meet the needs of patients. The culture is one of excellence and service which I love.
cons: The management expects a lot of employees without upholding the same values they expect to be displayed by those they lead. Employees often feel like they don’t matter and morale is low which is shown by the high turn over rates
